name: SlipStream
one_liner: Lightweight marina management for small harbors — slips, billing, maintenance, and guest communication

brief.problem: Small marinas (under 200 slips) use whiteboards, spreadsheets, and phone calls to manage slip assignments, waitlists, billing, and maintenance. Legacy marina software is expensive ($250-500+/mo) and designed for large operations.
brief.target_user: Independent marina operators and harbormasters at small-to-medium harbors (20-200 slips), especially in cruising hubs like La Paz, BCS
brief.proposed_solution: AI-powered marina management tool: automated billing, slip assignment optimization, maintenance scheduling, weather alerts, and guest communication. Priced for small operators at $50-100/mo.
brief.value_prop: Professional marina management at 1/5th the cost of enterprise software — built for small harbors, not mega-marinas

competition.reasoning: 15+ established vendors (Dockwa with 2,000+ marinas, Molo, HarbaMaster with free tier, MarinaOffice). Small marina niche is underserved but not empty.

team_fit.reasoning: Ben's La Paz move provides embedded, trust-based distribution that no remote competitor can replicate. Boating network provides warm intros. But Ben is not a marina operator; team lacks marina domain depth.

bootstrappability.reasoning: Standard web app, commodity tech, under $100 infrastructure. Needs polished UX for non-technical marina operators.

passive_potential.reasoning: SaaS billing is passive but marina operators need high-touch support and onboarding. Feature requests from a small customer base can be demanding.

side_project_viability.reasoning: Building MVP fits constraints. Customer acquisition + support at 4-8 hrs/week is tight for B2B SaaS with high-touch onboarding.

ai_leverage.reasoning: AI enhances (predictive maintenance, occupancy analytics, smart guest communication) but the core product is CRUD — slip database, billing, scheduling. Not AI-native.

revenue_clarity.reasoning: Marinas already pay $250-500+/mo for software. $50-100/mo is compelling undercut. Question is whether the smallest marinas will pay at all vs. sticking with spreadsheets.

market_timing.reasoning: Mature market with no technological inflection point. Timing advantage is personal (La Paz move), not market-driven.

workshop.sharpened_problem: Marina operators at small harbors juggle slip assignments, transient bookings, maintenance schedules, billing, and guest communication with a patchwork of spreadsheets, paper logs, and phone calls. Enterprise marina software exists but costs $250-500+/mo and is designed for 500+ slip operations. Small marinas can't justify the cost and are stuck with manual processes that lead to double-bookings, missed maintenance, and lost revenue from transient boaters they can't efficiently accommodate.
key_assumptions: Small marina operators will pay $50-100/mo for management software rather than continuing with spreadsheets
Ben's physical presence in La Paz provides enough distribution to reach critical mass in the cruising community
The BoatStash + SlipStream ecosystem creates enough synergy to justify building both products

variations.name: Transient Booking Widget
variations.description: Focus narrowly on transient/visitor slip bookings — an online booking widget marinas embed on their website. Simpler than full management suite.
variations.tradeoff: Much simpler to build and sell (one clear value prop), but lower ARPU and more direct competition from Dockwa's core feature.

variations.name: BoatStash Marina Edition
variations.description: Instead of separate products, add marina management features directly into BoatStash as a B2B tier.
variations.tradeoff: Leverages existing BoatStash brand and user base, avoids building two separate products. But dilutes BoatStash's consumer focus.

revenue_models.how_it_works: Monthly fee per marina for management suite
Free management tool + 5-10% commission on transient bookings processed through the platform

workshop.biggest_risk: Established competitors (Dockwa, Molo) could easily move downmarket with free or cheap tiers if the small marina segment proves attractive. Dockwa already has 2,000+ marinas and strong brand recognition.
workshop.unfair_advantage_needed: Ben's physical presence in the La Paz cruising community and the BoatStash user base as a referral channel. Without these, this is just another marina SaaS in a crowded market.

competitors.name: Dockwa
competitors.strengths: 2,000+ marinas, strong brand, modern UX, handles transient bookings well
competitors.weaknesses: Pricing may be high for small marinas, US-centric

competitors.name: HarbaMaster
competitors.strengths: Free tier makes it accessible to small marinas
competitors.weaknesses: Less modern UX, limited AI features

competitors.name: Spreadsheets / paper
competitors.strengths: Zero cost, familiar, no learning curve
competitors.weaknesses: No automation, error-prone, can't handle growth or transient bookings efficiently

market_size.tam: ~12,000 marinas in the US + ~3,000 in Mexico/Caribbean
market_size.sam: ~5,000 small independent marinas (under 200 slips) not using modern software
market_size.target_niche: Small marinas in cruising hubs (La Paz, Sea of Cortez, Caribbean) — estimated 500-1,000 facilities

trends.evidence: Marina industry is mature with steady demand. No major growth catalyst, but not declining either. Boating participation stable.
headwinds: Established competitors with large market share
Small marina operators resistant to change

distribution_channels.fit: Ben physically present, can demo to marina operators face-to-face
Cross-referral from boaters to marinas they use
Seven Seas Cruising Association, Cruisers Forum — active communities

moat_potential.explanation: Once a marina migrates their slip data, billing history, and workflows into SlipStream, switching cost is high. Combined with BoatStash ecosystem, creates a two-sided network effect.
moat_potential.time_to_moat: 12+ months — need significant adoption on both sides

tech_sketch.summary: Standard web application with database for slip management, billing integration (Stripe), scheduling system, and notification/communication layer. AI features are add-ons for maintenance prediction and guest communication.
tech_sketch.hard_technical_problems: None. This is fundamentally a well-designed CRUD application with billing. The AI components are enhancement layers, not core architecture challenges.

complexity.reasoning: More complex than a simple tool — needs proper billing, multi-tenant architecture, and enough features to replace spreadsheets. Not technically hard but requires polish and completeness to be useful.

side_project_feasible.explanation: Building the MVP is feasible at side-project pace. But B2B SaaS for non-technical marina operators requires high-touch onboarding and support that strains 4-8 hrs/week, especially when also building BoatStash.

real_blockers.blocker: Marina operators are change-resistant and require relationship-based selling
real_blockers.workaround: Ben's physical presence in La Paz enables in-person demos and hand-holding that remote competitors can't offer

real_blockers.blocker: Competing for Ben's bandwidth with BoatStash
real_blockers.workaround: Build BoatStash first, let marina relationships develop naturally, add SlipStream later as a natural extension

cost_to_operate.breakdown: Hosting ($20-30), Stripe fees (2.9% of billing processed), email/SMS ($10-20), AI API ($10-20)

key_risks.risk: Dockwa or HarbaMaster moves downmarket with free/cheap tier for small marinas
key_risks.mitigation: Focus on Mexico/Latin America cruising hubs where US competitors have weak presence

key_risks.risk: Building two products (BoatStash + SlipStream) at side-project pace spreads Ben too thin
key_risks.mitigation: Sequential approach: BoatStash first, SlipStream only if marina demand emerges organically

primary_model.name: SaaS Subscription
primary_model.how_it_works: Monthly subscription based on marina size. Includes slip management, billing, maintenance scheduling, and basic communication features.

time_to_first_dollar.estimate: 3-6 months after Ben's La Paz move (Nov 2026-Feb 2027)
time_to_first_dollar.how: In-person demos to La Paz marina operators after establishing relationships through BoatStash community presence

alternative_models.pros: Free tool attracts adoption, revenue scales with booking volume
alternative_models.cons: Directly competes with Dockwa's model, requires booking volume to generate revenue

alternative_models.pros: Single brand, cross-sell between boaters and marinas
alternative_models.cons: Dilutes BoatStash's consumer focus, complex pricing

monetization.pricing_psychology: Marina operators compare against enterprise software at $250-500/mo. Position SlipStream as 'professional marina management at small-business prices' — the value anchor is what they'd pay for Dockwa or MarinaOffice, making $49-99/mo feel like a bargain.

revenue_ceiling.realistic_monthly: $7,500-15,000 at steady state with side-project effort
revenue_ceiling.reasoning: 100-200 marinas at $49-99/mo is realistic over 18-24 months through community channels. Ceiling is modest because small marina market is limited and requires relationship-based sales.

summary:
SlipStream is a PROMISING idea with a clear niche, affordable price point, and a genuine unfair advantage in Ben's upcoming relocation to La Paz. The marina management software market is established with 15+ competitors, but most target medium-to-large operations at $250-500+/mo, leaving small marinas underserved. The product itself is technically straightforward and cheap to build and operate.

Top 3 Strengths: (1) Ben physically moving to La Paz provides embedded, trust-based distribution that no remote competitor can replicate. (2) Natural ecosystem synergy with BoatStash — B2B SlipStream + B2C BoatStash creates a two-sided boating platform. (3) Extremely low cost to build and operate with proven B2B SaaS model at $50-100/mo, well below alternatives.

Top 3 Concerns: (1) Established competition (Dockwa has 2,000+ marinas, HarbaMaster offers free tier) in a mature market with no technological inflection point. (2) High-touch, relationship-based sales required for change-resistant marina operators — difficult to scale at side-project pace beyond Ben's personal network. (3) Revenue ceiling is modest ($90K-180K ARR at realistic scale) — good side income but limited upside.

Recommended next steps: (1) Build BoatStash first — it's higher scoring and validates the community. (2) Build bare-bones SlipStream MVP by July 2026 before the La Paz move. (3) Upon arrival in La Paz (Aug 2026), demo to 5 marina operators. (4) If 2+ marinas commit as paying beta users, pursue; if not, focus on BoatStash.

Who should lead: Ben Battles.
